revision.text:
{{Infobox military structure |name=Bandarban Cantonment |location= [[Bandarban Sadar Upazila]], [[Bandarban District|Bandarban]] |image= |caption= |type= [[Cantonment]] |built= |materials= |used= |controlledby=[[Bangladesh Army]] |garrison= |current_commander= |battles= }} '''Bandarban Cantonment''' ({{lang-bn|বান্দরবন সেনানিবাস}}) is a [[cantonment]] located in [[Bandarban District|Bandarban]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.joinbangladesharmy.mil.bd/about-army/cantonment-locations |title=Cantonment Locations |work=Bangladesh Army |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150618152955/http://www.joinbangladesharmy.mil.bd/about-army/cantonment-locations |archivedate=2015-06-18 |accessdate=2015-07-11 }}</ref> The headquarter of 69th Infantry Brigade of [[Bangladesh Army]] locate here.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.travelkd.com/2014/02/a-to-z-information-of-nilgiri-hill-resort-tourist-spot-of-bandarban.html |title=Nilgir Resort Bandarban Information |work=travelkd.com |date=2015-02-25 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150424175235/http://www.travelkd.com/2014/02/a-to-z-information-of-nilgiri-hill-resort-tourist-spot-of-bandarban.html |archivedate=2015-04-24 |accessdate=2015-07-11 }}</ref> It is one of five cantonment in [[Chittagong Hill Tracts]] area.<ref name="tribune">{{cite news |last=Humphreys |first=Phil |url=http://www.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/2013/dec/06/peace-our-time |title=Peace in our time? |work=[[Dhaka Tribune]] |location=Dhaka |date=2013-12-06 |accessdate=2015-07-11 }}</ref>
The chief of this Cantonment is Brigadier General Nakib Ahmed Chowdhury.<ref>{{cite news |last=Ahmed |first=Gazi Towhid |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/bandarban-children-see-a-ray-of-light-16369 |title=Bandarban children see a ray of light |work=[[Daily Star (Bangladesh)]] |location=Dhaka |date=2014-03-20 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140529081049/http://www.thedailystar.net/bandarban-children-see-a-ray-of-light-16369 |archivedate=2014-05-29 |accessdate=2015-07-11 }}</ref>
== Organization == * 69 Infantry Brigade ** 12 East Bengal ** 18 East Bengal ** 29 Bangladesh Infantry Regiment * 7 Field Ambulance * 103 Brigade Signal Company * SSD, Bandarban * OSP -3<!-- == Key installations == === Bangladesh Army formations ===
-->
==Education== * Bandarban Cantonment Public School and College
== See also == * [[Comilla Cantonment]] * [[Alikadam Cantonment]] * [[Savar Cantonment]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{Coord|22.201670|N|92.213273|E|display=title}} {{Cantonments of Bangladesh}} {{Military of Bangladesh}}
[[Category:Military of Bangladesh]] [[Category:Cantonments of Bangladesh]]
{{Bangladesh-mil-stub}}

{{refimprove|date=June 2014}} The '''Bertrand Russell Peace Foundation''' was established in 1963. The foundation aims to continue the work of the philosopher and activist [[Bertrand Russell]] in the areas of peace, [[social justice]], and human rights, with a specific focus on the dangers of [[nuclear war]]. Its director was [[Ken Coates]]. Its general secretary, until 1969, was [[Ralph Schoenman]].
'''Spokesman Books''' is the publishing imprint of the Bertrand Russell Peace Foundation<ref>{{cite book |first1=Kenneth |last1=Blackwell |first2=Harry |last2=Ruja |first3=Sheila |last3=Turcon |title=A Bibliography of Bertrand Russell: I. Separate Publications II. Serial Publications III. Indexes |publisher=Routledge |year=2003 |isbn=1-134-81890-4 |page=47 }}</ref> and publishes books on politics, peace and disarmament, and history. ''[[The Spokesman]]'' is the journal of the BRPF, which reached its 100th issue in August 2008.
==Publications== *[[Ken Coates]] and Tony Topham, ''Participation or Control?'' (1967) *Jo O'Brien, ''Women's Liberation in Labour History'' (1972) *''After the Chilean Coup'' (1973) *[[Salvador Allende]], ''Chile: No More Dependence!'' (1973) *Ken Coates, ''Democracy in the Labour Party'' (1977) *Ken Coates and Tony Topham, ''The Shop Steward's Guide to the Bullock Report'' (1977) *[[Peter Jenkins (journalist)|Peter Jenkins]], ''Where Trotskyism Got Lost'' (1977) *Alan Roberts and [[Zhores Medvedev]], ''Hazards of Nuclear Power'' (1977) *[[Brian Sedgemore]], ''The How and Why of Socialism'' (1977), {{ISBN|0851241964}} *[[Michael Barratt Brown]] et al., ed., ''Full Employment'' (1978) *''[[Berufsverbote]] Condemned'' (1978) *''Trident - Nuclear Proliferation the British Way'' (2008) *''Obama's Afghan Dilemma'' (2008) *''Democracy Old and New'' (2008) *''[[Battle of Tskhinvali|Tskhinvali]]: Shock and Awe'' (2008). {{ISBN|9780851247571}}. Edited by [[Ken Coates]], with contributions from [[Gareth Peirce]], [[Moazzam Begg]], [[Vladimir Putin]], [[Mahmoud Darwish]], [[Saifedean Ammous]], [[Stephen F. Cohen]], [[Andrew Mackinlay|Andrew Mackinlay MP]], [[Mahmoud Darwish]], [[Jean Ziegler]], [[James Petras]], [[Mike Cooley (engineer) | Mike Cooley]], Trevor Griffiths and Ann Talbot. *[[Mike Cooley (engineer) | Mike Cooley]], 'Architect or Bee? The Human Price of Technology', Foreword by [[Frances O'Grady]] (2017) *[[Mike Cooley (engineer) | Mike Cooley]], 'Delinquent Genius: The Strange Affair of Man and His Technology' Foreword by [[Michael D. Higgins]]. {{ISBN|978 085124 878 3}} (2018).
In the '''Spokesman Pamphlets''' series there are 94 titles {{as of|2000|lc=y}}.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.spokesmanbooks.com/Spokesman/Spk%20Pamph/Spkpam%201.htm | title=Spokesman Pamphlets | publisher=Spokesman Books | accessdate=May 1, 2017}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Russell Tribunal]], for activities of Bertrand Russell Peace Foundation during [[Vietnam War]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.russfound.org/ Bertrand Russell Peace Foundation] * [http://www.spokesmanbooks.com/ Spokesman Books] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060827094103/http://www.bl.uk/onlinegallery/themes/voices/russell.html Speech by Bertrand Russell, at European Congress on Nuclear Disarmament (17 January 1959), Voices of History, British Library] - voice recording
{{anti-war}}
[[Category:Foundations based in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:1963 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Anti–nuclear weapons movement]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1963]] [[Category:Peace organizations]]

{{Infobox company | name = | logo = Blueline logo.svg | caption = | type = | genre = | fate = | predecessor = [[SEM Maritime Company]] | successor = | foundation = 2003 | founder = | defunct = | location_city = | location_country = | location = | locations = | area_served = [[Adriatic Sea]] | key_people = | industry = Passenger transportation
Freight transportation | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = SEM Maritime Company | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.blueline-ferries.com www.blueline-ferries.com] | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Blue Line International''' is a [[ferry]] company owned by the [[Croatia]]-based [[SEM Maritime Company]] (SMC). The Blue Line brand was established in 2003 as a marketing name for SMC's Croatia—Italy services, coinciding with the purchase of the [[MV Ancona|MV ''Ancona'']]. The company operated a regular around-the-year service between [[Ancona]] and [[Split (city)|Split]], alongside the seasonal lines Ancona—[[Hvar (town)|Hvar]] and Ancona—[[Vis (town)|Vis]]. ==Fleet== [[File:BlueLineAncona gobeirne.jpg|thumb|right|M/S ''Ancona'' in Ancona Harbour, Italy, 2010.]] ===Former ships=== {| class="wikitable" ! Ship || Built || In service || [[Gross register tonnage]] || Flag || Status as of 2010 |- | [[MV Split 1700|MV ''Split 1700'']] ||align="Center" | 1966 ||align="Center" | 2003–2010 || {{GRT|6,474}} || {{flag|Panama}} || |- | [[MV Ancona|MV ''Ancona'']] ||align="Center" | 1966 ||align="Center" | 2003-2010 || {{GRT|7,883}} || {{flag|Panama}} ||Scrapped in 2010 |- | [[MS Dalmatia|MV ''Dalmatia'']] ||align="Center" | 1978 ||align="Center" | 2011-2014 ||{{GT|12,078}} || {{flag|Panama}}||Scrapped in 2014 |- | [[MS Regina della Pace|MV ''Regina della Pace'']] ||align="Center" | 1979 ||align="Center" | 2010-2017 || {{GT|16,405}} || {{flag|Panama}} ||Sold to Ventouris Ferries as Rigel III |} |} ==References== {{Reflist}} * [http://www.faktaomfartyg.se/sem_maritime_company.htm Fakta om Fartyg: SEM Maritime Company / Blue Ferries] ==External links== {{Commons category|Blue Line International}} * [http://www.blueline-ferries.com Blue Line International web page] [[Category:Shipping companies of Croatia]] [[Category:Water transport in Croatia]] [[Category:Ferry companies of Croatia]] {{Transport-company-stub}} {{Croatia-stub}} {{Italy-company-stub}}

page.title: Church of St. Stephen, Donje Nerodimlje

revision.comment: removed parent categories of [[Category:Destroyed churches in Kosovo]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox religious building |building_name=Church of St. Stephen, Donje Nerodimlje
Црква Светог Стефана, Доње Неродимље |image= |caption=Church of St. Stephen |location=[[Donje Nerodimlje]], [[Kosovo]]{{ref label|status|a|}} |geo= |religious_affiliation=[[Serbian Orthodox]] |district= |consecration_year=14th century |status= |leadership= |website= |architect= |architecture_type= |architecture_style= |facade_direction= |year_completed= |construction_cost= |capacity= |length= |width= |width_nave= |height_max= |dome_quantity= |dome_height_outer= |dome_height_inner= |dome_dia_outer= |dome_dia_inner= |minaret_quantity= |minaret_height= |spire_quantity= |spire_height= |materials= }} '''Church of St. Stephen''' ({{lang-sr|Црква Светог Стефана}} / ''Crkva Svetog Stefana'') was a [[Serbian Orthodox Church|Serbian Orthodox church]] located in [[Donje Nerodimlje]], in the municipality of [[Uroševac]], [[Kosovo and Metohija]]. It belonged to the [[Diocese of Raška and Prizren]] of the [[Serbian Orthodox Church]] and it was destroyed by [[Albanians|Albanian]] extremists in 1999.[http://www.svetosavlje.org/biblioteka/Zitija/OdKosovaDoJadovna/OdKosovaDoJadovna28.htm Svetosavlje/ Destroyed, burned and looted churches, no.39] == Location == The church dedicated to St. Stephen, dating from the [[14th century]], was located in the valley of the river [[Nerodimka (river)|Nerodimka]], at the cemetery in [[Donje Nerodimlje]], five kilometers west of [[Uroševac]]. The church was rebuilt in 1996. After the arrival of the US [[Kosovo Force|KFOR]] forces in 1999, the church was damaged, burned and destroyed by Albanians.[http://www.rastko.rs/kosovo/raspeto/crkve/cr09.html Raspeto Kosovo] == Gallery == {{Empty section|date=March 2016}} ==Notes== {| style="margin-left:13px; line-height:150%" |align="right" valign="top"|a.   |{{note|status}}{{Kosovo-note}} |} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://dan-veterana.blogspot.rs/2011/05/blog-post_19.html#.VruwGfnhDIV The list of destroyed and desecrated churches in Kosovo and Metohija June-October 1999 (Списак уништених и оскрнављених цркава на Косову и Метохији јун-октобар 1999)] {{coord missing|Serbia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Church of St. Stephen, Donje Nerodimlje}} [[Category:Serbian Orthodox church buildings in Kosovo]] [[Category:Medieval Serbian sites in Kosovo]] [[Category:Destroyed churches in Kosovo]] [[Category:Persecution of Serbs]] [[Category:Former Serbian Orthodox churches]] [[Category:14th-century Serbian Orthodox church buildings]] [[Category:1400 establishments in Europe]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in the 1400s]] [[Category:Ferizaj]] [[Category:Cultural heritage of Kosovo]] {{church-stub}} {{Kosovo-stub}}

'''Count Basic''' are an [[Austria]]n band who play a variety of [[R&B]], [[trip hop]], [[acid jazz]] and [[smooth jazz]]. The band's principal members were guitarist Peter Legat and the two vocalists Kelli Sae and Valerie Etienne but the band decided to go on only with Kelli Sae after the first album.
==Discography==
*1995 ''Life Think It Over'' *1996 ''The Remix Hit Collection, Vol. 1'' *1996 ''Movin' in the Right Direction'' *1997 ''Live'' *2000 ''[[Trust Your Instincts]]'' *2002 ''[[BIGGER & BRIGHTER|Bigger & Brighter]]'' *2007 ''[[Love and Light (Count Basic album)|Love & Light]]''
== External links == *[http://www.countbasic.com/ Count Basic Official Site]
{{Authority control}} [[Category:Smooth jazz ensembles]] [[Category:Acid jazz ensembles]]
{{europe-band-stub}}

revision.comment: -[[Category:News agencies]]; ±[[Category:Media in the Czech Republic]]→[[Category:News agencies based in the Czech Republic]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Czech News Agency | image = CTKlogo.png | type = [[Public service]] | foundation = {{Start date|1993}} | location = [[Prague]], [[Czech Republic]] | key_people =Jiří Majstr
([[General Director]]) | industry = [[News media]] | products = [[Wire service]] | area_served = Worldwide | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = 273 | parent = | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.ctk.eu ctk.eu] | footnotes = }} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} The '''Czech News Agency''' ({{lang-cs|Česká tisková kancelář}}), abbreviated to '''ČTK''', is a national [[public service]] [[news agency]] in the [[Czech Republic]]. It publishes in [[Czech language|Czech]], [[Slovak language|Slovak]], and English. Founded on 28 October 1918, on the same day as [[Czechoslovakia]]'s formation,{{cite book |title=Czech Republic |last=Edmondson |first=Vlaďka |author2=Short, David |year=1999 |publisher=Clio Press |location=Oxford |isbn=978-1-85109-304-5 |page=342 }} the company has been owned by the government and used by the various regimes in the [[Czech lands]] since then. Following the [[Velvet Revolution]] of 1989, the government ceased interfering in editorial decisions. In 1993 the government relinquished control of the agency, which has since been governed by a board of seven people elected by the [[Chamber of Deputies of the Parliament of the Czech Republic|lower house of Parliament]]. Members of the board are not allowed to be politically active.[http://www.ctk.eu/&refer=us www.ctk.eu]{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The agency's state [[subsidy]] was discontinued in 1996. It was renamed from Czechoslovak to Czech News Agency on 1 January 1993 when Czechoslovakia split. CTK, however, stayed active in the Slovak market. Its former Slovak part is a separate company under a different set-up called TASR [[News Agency of the Slovak Republic]].[http://www.tasr.sk/30.axd?lang=1033&refer=us www.tasr.sk] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721220951/http://www.tasr.sk/30.axd?lang=1033&refer=us |date=21 July 2011 }} ==Footnotes== {{reflist}} [[Category:News agencies based in the Czech Republic]] {{CzechRepublic-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Germany}} "Dieser Traum darf niemals sterben" | image = | caption = | year = 1991 | country = Germany | artist = Alfons Weindorf,
Jutta Niedhardt,
Helmut Frey,
Eberhard Wilhelm,
Klaus Pröpper,
Clemens Weindorf | as = Atlantis 2000 | with = | language = German | languages = | composer = Helmut Frey | lyricist = Alfons Weindorf | conductor = Herman Weindorf | place = 18th | points = 10 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1991de from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = Frei zu leben | prev_link = Frei zu leben | next = Träume sind für alle da | next_link = Träume sind für alle da }} '''"Dieser Traum darf niemals sterben"''' ("This dream must never die") was the [[Germany|German]] entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1991]], performed in [[German language|German]] by [[Atlantis 2000]]. The song was selected to represent Germany by [[televoting]]."[http://knockknockeurosongs.blogspot.se/2010/09/germany-1991.html Germany 1991]", Knock Knock Eurosongs, 8 September 2010. Retrieved 24 April 2012.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011|reason=Better source needed}} The song was performed seventeenth on the night (following [[Finland]]'s [[Kaija]] with "[[Hullu yö]]" and preceding [[Belgium]]'s [[Clouseau (band)|Clouseau]] with "[[Geef het op]]"). At the close of voting, it had received 10 points, placing 18th in a field of 22. The song is a dramatic ballad, with the band singing that humanity must learn to overcome its propensity towards hate in order to achieve unity. "This dream", they sing, "must never die". Atlantis 2000 also recorded an English version of the song, entitled "Never Ending Dream". It was succeeded as [[Germany in the Eurovision Song Contest|German representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1992|1992 Contest]] by [[Wind (band)|Wind]] with "[[Träume sind für alle da]]". == References == == External links == * [http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=307 Official Eurovision Song Contest site, history by year] * [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1991de Detailed info & lyrics, Diggiloo Thrush] {{s-start}} {{succession box | before="[[Frei zu leben]]"
by [[Chris Kempers]] and [[Daniel Kovac]] | title=[[Germany in the Eurovision Song Contest]] | years=[[Eurovision Song Contest 1991|1991]] | after="[[Träume sind für alle da]]"
by [[Wind (band)|Wind]] }} {{s-end}} {{Germany in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 1991}} [[Category:Eurovision songs of Germany]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of 1991]] [[Category:1991 songs]] {{germany-stub}} {{1990s-song-stub}}

{{Infobox road | country = EUR | type = E | route = 762 | length_km = 382 | map = | map_alot = | direction_a = North | terminus_a = [[Sarajevo]] | junction = [[Nikšić]],
[[Podgorica]],
[[Shkodër]] | direction_b = South | terminus_b = [[Tirana]] | countries = [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]],
[[Montenegro]],
[[Albania]] }} '''European route E 762''' is a road part of the [[International E-road network]]. It begins in [[Sarajevo]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]], [[Montenegro]] and ends in [[Albania]]. == Route == * {{flag|Bosnia and Herzegovina}} ** {{jct|country=EUR|E|761}} [[Sarajevo]] ** [[Foča]] * {{flag|Montenegro}} ** [[Plužine]] ** [[Nikšić]] ** {{jct|country=EUR|E|65|E|80}} [[Podgorica]] * {{flag|Albania}} ** {{jct|country=EUR|E|851}} [[Shkodër]] ** {{jct|country=EUR|E|851}} [[Lezhë]] ** [[Tirana]] ==External links== * [http://www.unece.org/trans/conventn/MapAGR2007.pdf Map of E-road] * [http://www.elbruz.org/eroads/E762.htm International E-road network] {{E-road}} {{DEFAULTSORT:European Route E762}} [[Category:International E-road network|799762]] [[Category:Roads in Albania|E762]] [[Category:Roads in Bosnia and Herzegovina|E762]] [[Category:Roads in Montenegro|E762]] {{Europe-road-stub}} {{Albania-transport-stub}}

revision.text:
[[Image:fibreLNB.jpg|thumb|right |An optical output LNB showing both the fibre connection (right) and the electrical connection for power]] [[Image:Optical fibre.jpg|thumb|right |Close-up of fibre optic cable stripped back to show the six layers of construction - the fibre at the centre surrounded by the core, a buffer layer, wound steel armour, [[Kevlar]] strands, and the PVC jacket]] '''Fibre satellite distribution''' is a technology that enables [[satellite TV]] signals from an [[Antenna (radio)|antenna]] to be distributed using an [[optical fibre]] cable infrastructure and then converted to electrical signals for use with conventional [[set-top box]] receivers.
Particularly applicable to satellite TV distribution systems in a [[Multi-family residential|multi-dwelling unit]], such as a block of flats (but useful in smaller domestic distribution systems too), such a hybrid fibre/electrical system reduces the cabling required, reduces signal noise and interference, and provides for an easy upgrade to increase the number of [[Tuner (television)|tuners]] connected at each dwelling.<ref>"[http://www.yateley.net/SatByF/contents/en-uk/SatPro.pdf Giving co-ax the axe]" ''What Satellite & Digital TV'' (April, 2009) p130-131</ref>
Conventional systems that distribute the electrical satellite [[Intermediate frequency|IF]] signal via a star network of [[coaxial cable]] require one relatively short cable run from the central distribution equipment to each tuner connected to the system, whereas in a fibre system, cables can be very long, and split at successive locations, in a tree structure without detriment to the reception.
==Advantages== The primary benefit of using optical fibre for a satellite TV IF distribution system is that the fibre can carry the entire received spectrum on one cable, which can then be split to provide for multiple tuners, without requiring a separate feed from the antenna to each tuner. Additional outlets can be added to increase the number of receivers within one home without accessing the central antenna or main infrastructure.
Fibre cable is cheap in long runs, retailing at about twice the price of equivalent copper coaxial cable, but replacing four runs of coaxial cable with a single fibre cable. It is also much smaller than the coaxial signal cable used for electrical IF distribution, but robust and flexible. The losses in a fibre system are almost negligible so very long cable runs of hundreds of metres are possible without any signal reinforcement.
Because the signal is carried as a beam of light, it is impervious to the electrical interference that even the best coaxial satellite cable may suffer, and cables can be safely and conveniently run alongside mains power cables. Power consumption is also lower than an equivalent electrical system.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.triax.co.uk/Products/Fibre%20Optic%20Solutions.aspx |title = Fibre Optic Solutions |publisher = Triax |accessdate = January 13, 2010 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100411061443/http://www.triax.co.uk/Products/Fibre%20Optic%20Solutions.aspx |archivedate = April 11, 2010 |df = }}</ref> <ref>[http://www.triax.uk/media/com_redshopb/documents/originals/products/19801-19900/gb-triax-fibre-optic-sat-05-207-19849.pdf ''SAT Fibre Optics''] Triax. May 2016 Retrieved October 27, 2017</ref> <ref>[http://www.tele-satellite.com/TELE-satellite-0909/eng/gi.pdf ''Global Invacom Optical LNB: The Satellite Reception Revolution''] Tele-Satellite August 2009 Retrieved December 31, 2016</ref>
==Development== [[Image:fibreSplitter.jpg|thumb|right |An eight-way optical signal splitter to feed eight virtual LNBs or further splitters from a single optical feed]] While optical fibre has been used for telephone and Internet backbone data, and even for television and multimedia carriage for terrestrial cable, for many years, use for satellite IF distribution has been held back by considerations of cost and installation convenience.
However, since about 2007, UK company, Global Invacom (which also markets domestic and communal satellite reception and distribution equipment, including SCR [[single cable distribution]] equipment) has developed a low cost standardised system of optical fibre distribution suitable for domestic installations and small or medium commercial communal dish systems.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://globalinvacom.com/products/fibremdu-virtual-converters.php |title=Fibre optic distribution products information |publisher= Global Invacom | accessdate=January 13, 2010 }}</ref>
The development was assisted by [[Astra (satellites)|Astra]] satellite operator [[SES S.A.|SES]] both with advice and financial support in the form of the prize for the Astra Innovation Contest run by Astra in 2007, which Global Invacom won for the proposal and initial development of optical fibre distribution systems for satellite TV.<ref>{{cite press release |publisher=SES ASTRA |date=September 28, 2007 |url=http://nl.ses.com/4233325/news/2007/4434481|title= Global Communications, Invacom, And Era Technology Winners of the SES ASTRA Innovation Contest |accessdate = January 26, 2012}}</ref>
== How it works == [[Image:fibreConverter.jpg|thumb|right |A virtual LNB with four electrical outputs for four tuners]] The complete spectrum of Ku-band satellite reception stretches from 10.70 GHz-12.75 GHz across two signal [[Polarization (waves)|polarisations]], or a [[Bandwidth (signal processing)|bandwidth]] of about 4000 MHz. This cannot be carried on a single coaxial cable and so in a conventional satellite reception system, just one of four sub-bands (received in vertical and horizontal polarization, and high and low frequency,) is sent from the antenna to the indoor receiver as 0.95 GHz-2.15 GHz IF. Which sub-band is required is signalled from the receiver to the antenna’s LNB by a 13/18V and 0/22 kHz tone on the LNB supply sent up the same coaxial cable. In a single antenna distribution system, special quattro LNB supplies all four sub-bands at once, from four outputs and these are supplied as required to each of the multiple outlets connected to an IF [[multiswitch]].<ref>Bains, Geoff. "Installing Home IF Distribution" ''What Satellite & Digital TV'' (June, 2007) p47-51</ref>
In an optical fibre system at the LNB the four sub-bands are "stacked" in frequency, one above the other, at 0.95 GHz-3.0 GHz (the whole frequency range received in vertical polarisation) and 3.4 GHz-5.45 GHz (horizontal polarisation) and transmitted together as a modulated optical signal down the fibre cable using a 1310 nm [[semiconductor laser]].
The losses in the cable are extremely small (in the region of 0.3dB/km) and the Global Invacom optical LNB output can be split up to 32 ways with a cable length of up to 10 km between the LNB and the receiver.
At, or near, the receiver, the optical signal is converted back to the traditional electrical signal with a virtual multiswitch, providing one or more outputs that “appear” to the receiver as a conventional LNB.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.globalinvacom.com/products/fibreopticlnb2.php |title= FibreMDU Optical LNB |publisher= Global Invacom | accessdate=January 12, 2010 }}</ref>
==Practical considerations== [[Image:fibreCable.jpg|thumb|right |A 1m optical fibre cable with fitted connectors for other fibre distribution equipment]] Although the hybrid optical fibre/electrical system provides many advantages over electrical IF distribution to widespread or complex systems, it also requires a new approach by installers familiar only with electrical installations.
The single mode fibre cables use an 8μm fibre armoured with a steel wrap and Kevlar strands inside a plastic jacket. Fibre cable cannot be easily joined (an expensive [[fusion splicer]] is required for reliable joints) but pre-made cables with FC type screw-on [[Optical fibre connector|connectors]] (mechanically similar in use, but smaller, to the F-connectors used for electrical satellite IF) are available in lengths from 1m to 100m. The same connectors are used on all the optical components of a system, including the optical LNB, splitters, cable joiners, virtual LNB units, etc.
The cables must be properly prepared (the end of the fibre itself cleaned) before connections are made and provision must be made to attenuate the LNB signal, to avoid overloading the receiver, if it is not split between receivers as there is so little attenuation inherent in the cable.
The optical LNB requires two cables connected – the fibre signal cable and a separate F-connector cable to supply the 12V supply to power the LNB electronics. If the installation is a conversion from an electrical system to fibre, an existing redundant coaxial signal cable can be used for the power supply.
==See also== *[[SES S.A.|SES]] *[[Astra (satellites)|Astra]] * [[Satellite television]] * [[Satellite dish]] * [[Microwave antenna]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.onastra.com Official Astra consumers/viewers' site] *[http://www.ses.com/ Official SES trade/industry site] *[http://globalinvacom.com Global Invacom]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fibre Satellite Distribution}} [[Category:Broadcasting]] [[Category:Television technology]] [[Category:Satellite television]]

fill out references, harmonise accessdate format per [[MOS:DATEUNIFY]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
'''Grinlandia''' ({{lang-ru|Гринландия}}) is the [[fantasy world]] where most of the novels and short stories of [[Alexander Grin]] take place. The name of the country is never mentioned by the author himself, and the name Grinlandia was suggested in 1934 by literary critic [[Korneliy Zelinsky]] <ref>Зелинский К. Жизнь и творчество А. С. Грина. // Грин А. С. Фантастические новеллы. — М., 1934</ref><ref>[http://22-91.ru/etot-den-v-istorii-sssr/737/strana-grinlandija Страна Гринландия] (retrieved Feb. 24, 2013)</ref> and adopted by Grin's fans since then.
The [[Alexander Grin museum (Theodosia)|Alexander Grin museum]] in [[Feodosia|Theodosia]] contains the reconstructed map of the land.<ref name="kimmeria">{{cite web|url=http://www.kimmeria.com/kimmeria/feodosiya/museum_grin_land.htm|title=Страна ГринЛандия - музей Александра Грина|publisher=kimmeria.com|accessdate=2016-04-15}}</ref><ref name="narod">{{cite web|url=http://grinlandia.narod.ru/map/map.htm |title=Карта Гринландии | Map of Grinlandia |publisher=grinlandia.narod.ru|accessdate=2016-04-15}}</ref>
It is a land by the ocean, apparently far from Europe (as some characters speak about "sailing to Europe") but populated by people with vaguely Western European names and appearance.
The language spoken in Grinlandia is also never identified (though the novels themselves are written in Russian). There are several cities ([[Liss (Grinlandia)|Liss]], [[Zurbagan]], [[San Riole]], etc.) mentioned in several of the novels, but none of them are identified as a capital.
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Fictional countries]]

{{Infobox spaceflight | name = Intelsat 707 | image = | image_caption = | mission_type = Communications | operator = [[Intelsat]] | website = | COSPAR_ID = 1996-015A{{cite web|url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1995-023A|title=Intelsat 707|first=Goddard Space Flight Center|last=NASA|work=NSSDC Master Catalog|accessdate=April 28, 2017}} | SATCAT = 23816 | mission_duration = 15 years design life | spacecraft_bus = [[Spacebus|SSL-1300]] | manufacturer = [[Space Systems/Loral|SSL]] | dry_mass = {{convert|1450|kg}} | launch_mass = {{convert|4175|kg}} | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|14 March 1996, 07:11:01|timezone=yes}} UTC{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|title=Launch Log|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|work=Jonathan's Space Page|accessdate=April 28, 2017}} | launch_rocket = [[Ariane 4]]4 LP H10-3 | launch_site = [[Guiana Space Centre|Kourou]] [[ELA-2]] | launch_contractor = | entered_service = | disposal_type = Decommissioned | deactivated = {{end-date|January 2011}} | orbit_epoch = April 27, 2017{{cite web|url=https://www.n2yo.com/satellite/?s=23816|title=INTELSAT 707|work=N2yo.com|accessdate=April 28, 2017}} | orbit_reference = [[Geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[geostationary orbit|Geostationary]] | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|36,004.3|km}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|36,602.5|km}} | orbit_inclination = 3.5° | orbit_period = 1,462.2 minutes | orbit_semimajor = {{convert|42674|km|mi}} | orbit_longitude = 157° E | apsis = gee | trans_band = 26 [[C band (IEEE)|C band]]
14 [[Ku band]] | trans_frequency = | trans_bandwidth = | trans_capacity = | trans_coverage = [[Europe]], [[The Americas|Americas]], [[Brazil]] | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = | trans_HPBW = | programme = ''Intelsat VII'' | previous_mission = [[Intelsat 706|Intelsat VII-F7]] | next_mission = [[Intelsat 708|Intelsat VII-F8]] }} '''Intelsat 707''' (also known as '''IS-707''' and '''Intelsat 7-F7''') is a [[geostationary]] [[communication]] [[satellite]] that was built by [[Space Systems/Loral]] ('''SSL'''). It is located in the orbital position of 53 degrees west longitude and it is currently in an [[inclined orbit]]. The same is owned by [[Intelsat]]. The satellite was based on the LS-1300 platform and its estimated useful life was 15 years.{{cite web|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/intelsat-7a.htm|title=Intelsat-7A (706, 707, 708)|first=Krebs|last=Gunter|work=Gunters Space Page|accessdate=April 28, 2017}} The satellite was successfully launched into space on March 14, 1996, at 07:11, using an [[Ariane 4]] vehicle from the [[Guiana Space Centre]], [[Kourou]], [[French Guiana]]. It had a launch mass of 4,180 kg. The Intelsat 707 carried 26 [[C band (IEEE)|C band]] and 14 [[Ku band]] transponders to provide Europe and the Americas with 3 television channels and 22,500 telephone circuits after parking over the eastern coast of [[Brazil]]. ==See also== {{Portal|Spaceflight}} * [[1996 in spaceflight]] == External links == * [http://www.tbs-satellite.com/tse/online/sat_intelsat_707.html Intelsat 707] TBS satellite * [http://www.satbeams.com/satellites?norad=23816 Intelsat 707] SatBeams == References == {{reflist|2}} {{Orbital launches in 1996}} {{Intelsat}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1996]] [[Category:Intelsat satellites]] {{US-spacecraft-stub}}

revision.text:
'''Kadimah''' ('''{{lang-he|קדימה}}''', lit. ''Onward'') (German: '''A.V. Kadima Wien''') was the first [[Jew]]ish [[student association]] in [[Vienna]], founded many years before [[Theodor Herzl]] became the leading spokesman of the [[Zionism|Zionist movement]]. ==History== The national Jewish and Zionist ''Kadimah'' was founded by [[Nathan Birnbaum]] together with Moses Schnirer, [[Ruben Bierer]] and [[Peretz Smolenskin]] in Vienna on 25 October 1882.
Well-known members of ''Kadimah'' include [[Sigmund Freud]], Isidor Schalit and [[Fritz Löhner-Beda]].
Members of the Kadimah founded the Jewish [[studentenverbindung]] ''Hasmonaea Czernowitz'' in 1891, ''Moriah Vienna'' in 1893 and ''Barissia Radautz'' in 1912.
''Kadimah'' itself was liquidated by then [[Nazism|Nazi]]-ruled official authorities in August 1938.
== References == {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * Ludwig Rosenhek (editor), ''Festschrift zur Feier des 100. Semesters der akademischen Verbindung Kadimah 1883-1933'', Wien 1933 * Harriet Zivia Pass, ''Kadimah: Jewish Nationalism in Vienna before Herzl'', Columbia 1969
{{Jewish-org-stub}} {{Austria-stub}}
{{Authority control}} [[Category:Zionism in Austria]] [[Category:Zionist organizations]] [[Category:Jews and Judaism in Vienna]] [[Category:Jewish Austrian history]] [[Category:Jewish Austro-Hungarian history]]

[[Brest Voblast|Brest Province]] |leader_title = |leader_name = |established_title = |established_date = |area_magnitude = |area_total_km2 = |area_land_km2 = |area_water_km2 = |population_as_of = |population_note = |population_total = |population_metro = |population_density_km2 = |timezone = [[Eastern European Time|EET]] |utc_offset = +2 |timezone_DST = [[Eastern European Summer Time|EEST]] |utc_offset_DST = +3 |coordinates = {{coord|53|06|0|N|26|09|0|E|region:PL_type:city|display=inline,title}} |elevation_m = |postal_code = |area_code = |blank_name = |blank_info = |website = |footnotes = }} '''Litva''' ({{lang-be|Litva}}, {{lang-pl|Litwa}}) is a village in [[Belarus]]. It is located in the [[Baranavichy]] district, [[Brest Voblast|Brest Province]], 120 km south of the [[Capital (political)|capital]] [[Minsk]]. == External links == * [http://www.maplandia.com/belarus/brest/litva/ Location including the places] [[Category:Villages in Belarus]] [[Category:Populated places in Brest Region]] {{Belarus-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''mudbrick stamp''' or '''brick seal''' of [[Mesopotamia]] are [[impression seal|impression]] or [[stamp seal]]s made upon bricks or [[mudbrick]]. The inscribed seal is in [[mirror]] reverse on the 'mold', mostly with [[cuneiform]] inscriptions, and the foundation mudbricks are often part of the memorializing of temples, or other structures, as part of a "[[foundation deposit]]", a common honoring or invocation to a specific god or protector. ==Example mudbrick seal== [[File:Stamp Lasha Louvre AO27586.jpg|290px|thumb|Brick "stamp mold" for the King of [[Larsa]], [[Sin-Iddinam]]. (for Sun God, Utu, [[foundation deposit]] of temple) ]] The brick stamping mold for [[Sin-Iddinam]] of [[Larsa]] is housed in the Louvre. It is a nearly complete mold, with an inscription in cuneiform to the Sun God, [[Utu]], as a [[foundation deposit]] for the god's temple, the Ebbabar. ==Galley== File:Clay seal AF12903 mp3h8659.jpg|Ancient Egypt
later clay [[impression seal|seal impression]], Dynasty 26, with name of an undetermined king Psamtik ===Ancient Roman bricks=== {{Commons category|Ancient Roman brick stamps}} File:Museum Quintana - Ziegelstempel.jpg|Ancient Roman brick, with inscription ==External links== *[http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3501/3860282444_d8cb4e7837.jpg High Res photo of stamp from Mesopotamia]; [http://www.flickriver.com/photos/mharrsch/tags/mesopotamia/ Article] *[http://neareastern.berkeley.edu/hibeh/fun/mudbrick.htm Dig site with stamped mudbrick] [[Category:Bricks]] [[Category:Ancient Near and Middle East clay objects]] {{MEast-stub}}

{{Infobox Network | name = Radio Slovakia International | logo = | country = {{SVK}} | network_type = [[Radio network]] | available = International | owner = [[Rozhlas a televízia Slovenska]] | key_people = Mária Mikušová (Teamleader) | launch_date = 4 January 1993 | past_names = | website = http://en.rsi.rtvs.sk/ |}} '''Radio Slovakia International''' ('''RSI''') is [[Slovakia]]'s official [[international broadcasting|internet-based international broadcaster]]. The station was created almost simultaneously with the [[Slovak National Council's Declaration of Independence of the Slovak Nation|emergence]] of independent [[Slovakia]] and began broadcasting on 4 January 1993. Its duties were laid down as providing listeners in other countries with information about the new state and maintaining contact with the numerous expatriate [[Slovaks|Slovak]] communities around the world. Organizationally, it is a part of the [[Government-owned corporation|state-owned]] nationwide [[public broadcasting]] organization [[Rozhlas a televízia Slovenska]] ''(Radio and Television Slovakia)''. RSI's programmes are broadcast in [[English language|English]], [[German language|German]], [[French language|French]], [[Russian language|Russian]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]], and, for expatriates, [[Slovak language|Slovak]]. Its daily 30-minute magazine programmes contain news from [[Slovakia]], features on the Slovak economy, sciences, culture, geography, environment, sports, examples of the spoken, written, and musical arts, and portraits of important personalities. Radio Slovakia International broadcasts worldwide via internet and via the [[WRN Broadcast|World Radio Network]] platform.[http://mt-shortwave.blogspot.com/2010/12/rsi-will-continue-daily-programs-on-wrn.html ''Monday, December 27, 2010: RSI will continue daily programs on WRN'', Markmonitor.com, Mountain View, CA, quoting a posting by Radio Slovakia International at Radio Netherlands Media Network's blog].Accessed: 1 March 2011. == Frequencies == {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" !'''Town - Transmitter''' !'''Frequency''' !'''[[Effective radiated power|ERP]]''' !'''Time''' !'''Changing with''' |- |[[Bratislava]] - Mýtna 1 || 98,9 [[MHz]] || 0,20 [[Watt|kW]] || 18:00–6:00 h. || [[Rádio Patria]] |} ===Shortwave transmissions today=== Radio Slovakia International stopped broadcasting on shortwave from Slovakia, but is now relayed on two [[WRMI]] frequencies (11580kHz & 5850kHz) and via Shortwave Service in Germany (6005kHz) ====Former English-language schedule and frequencies==== 0100-0130 to North America on 5930 kHz (summer) and 7230 kHz (winter), and to South America on 9440 kHz
0700-0730 to Australasia on 9440 and 11650 kHz (summer), and 13715 and 15460 kHz (winter)
1630-1700 to Western Europe on 5920 kHz (summer only)
1730-1800 to Western Europe on 6055 kHz
1730-1800 to Western Europe on 5915 kHz (winter only)
1830-1900 to Western Europe on 5920 kHz (summer only) and 6055 kHz
1930-2000 to Western Europe on 5915 kHz (winter only) and 7345 kHz
==See also== * [[Rozhlas a televízia Slovenska]] ''(Radio and Television Slovakia)'', the Slovak publicly funded radio and television broadcaster * [[List of international radio broadcasters]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://en.rsi.rtvs.sk/ Radio Slovakia International official website] {{en icon}} {{World Radio Network}} {{coord missing|Slovakia}} [[Category:Radio stations in Slovakia]] [[Category:External services (broadcasting)]] [[Category:Radio stations established in 1993]] [[Category:1993 establishments in Slovakia]] [[Category:Radio and Television Slovakia]]

revision.comment: USA is deprecated, per [[MOS:NOTUSA]], and correct [[MOS:OVERLINK|overlinking]] of common places using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
'''The Messengers Choir''' was an [[East Africa]]n gospel group based in the United States. Before the break-up they were considered the first gospel choir of African origin to be formed and based in the United States.
The group was formed in [[New Jersey]], USA. The 30+ member ensemble blended elements of African gospel and American popular music. The group was an integral part of the Allegheny East Conference [[Seventh-day Adventist Church]] Festivals.
==References== * Official Website [http://www.messengerssongs.org] * Public Eye [http://www.publiceyesite.org/blog/?p=381]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Messengers Choir, The}} [[Category:American gospel musical groups]]
{{music-org-stub}} {{Africa-music-stub}}

page.title: Timeline of the Argentine Civil Wars

revision.text:
{{Infobox military conflict | conflict = Argentine Civil Wars | partof = | image = Guerra Civil.jpg | image_size = 250 | caption = From top left: [[Battle of Arroyo Grande]], execution of [[Manuel Dorrego]], [[Battle of Pavón]], death of [[Juan Lavalle]], murder of [[Facundo Quiroga]], [[Battle of Caseros]], [[Battle of Famaillá]], [[Battle of Vuelta de Obligado]]. | date = 1814-1876 | place = [[Argentina]]
[[Uruguay]] | coordinates = | map_type = | latitude = | longitude = | map_size = | map_caption = | map_label = | territory = | result = [[Federalization of Buenos Aires]]
Sanction of a [[federalism|federal]] [[Argentine Constitution of 1853|Constitution]] | status = | combatant1 = [[File:Flag of Artigas.svg|22px]] [[Federales (Argentina)|Federales]]
[[Image:Flag of the National Party (Uruguay).svg|border|22px]] [[National Party (Uruguay)|Blancos]] | combatant2 = [[File:Flag of Unitarian Party (Navy).svg|23px]] [[Unitarian Party|Unitarians]]
[[File:Flag of Colorado Party (Uruguay).svg|23px]] [[Colorado Party (Uruguay)|Colorados]] | combatant3 = | commander1 = [[File:Flag of Artigas.svg|22px]] [[Juan Manuel de Rosas]]
[[File:Flag of Artigas.svg|22px]] [[Manuel Dorrego]] {{KIA}}
[[File:Flag of Artigas.svg|22px]] [[Justo José de Urquiza]] {{KIA}}
[[File:Flag of Artigas.svg|22px]] [[Francisco Ramírez (governor)|Francisco Ramírez]] {{KIA}}
[[File:Flag of Artigas.svg|22px]] [[Facundo Quiroga]]{{KIA}}
[[File:Flag of Artigas.svg|22px]] [[Chacho Peñaloza]]{{KIA}}
[[Image:Flag of the National Party (Uruguay).svg|border|22px]] [[Manuel Oribe]] | commander2 = [[File:Flag of Unitarian Party (Navy).svg|23px]] [[Bartolomé Mitre]]
[[File:Flag of Unitarian Party (Navy).svg|23px]] [[Bernardino Rivadavia]]
[[File:Flag of Unitarian Party (Navy).svg|23px]] [[Juan Lavalle]]{{KIA}}
[[File:Flag of Unitarian Party (Navy).svg|23px]] [[José María Paz]] {{POW}}
[[File:Flag of Unitarian Party (Navy).svg|23px]] [[Domingo Faustino Sarmiento]]
[[File:Flag of Colorado Party (Uruguay).svg|23px]] [[Fructuoso Rivera]] | commander3 = | units1 = | units2 = | units3 = | strength1 = | strength2 = | strength3 = | casualties1 = | casualties2 = | casualties3 = | notes = }} The '''[[Argentine Civil Wars]]''' were a series of [[internecine war]]s that took place in [[Argentina]] from 1814 to 1876. These conflicts were separate from the [[Argentine War of Independence]] (1810 — 1820), though they first arose during this period. The main antagonists were, on a geographical level, [[Buenos Aires Province]] against the other provinces of modern Argentina, and on a political level, the [[Federales (Argentina)|Federal Party]] against the [[Unitarian Party]]. The central cause of the conflict was the excessive [[Centralized government|centralism]] advanced by Buenos Aires leaders and, for a long period, the monopoly on the use of the [[Port of Buenos Aires]] as the sole means for international commerce. Other participants at specific times included [[Banda Oriental|Uruguay]], and the [[British Empire|British]] and [[Second French Empire|French]] empires, notably in the [[French blockade of the Río de la Plata]] of 1838 and in the [[Anglo-French blockade of the Río de la Plata]] that ended in 1850. == Timeline == {{expand section|date=March 2016}} ===1829=== * [[Juan Manuel de Rosas]] and [[Juan Lavalle]] sign the [[Cañuelas Pact]]. * [[Juan Manuel de Rosas]] is elected governor of Buenos Aires. ===1830=== * [[José María Paz]] defeats [[Facundo Quiroga]] in the [[battle of Oncativo]]. * Paz establish the [[Unitarian League]]. * [[Buenos Aires]], [[Entre Ríos Province|Entre Ríos]] and [[Santa Fe Province|Santa Fe]] sign the [[Pacto Federal|Federal Pact]]. ===1831=== * Mendoza and Córdoba join the Federal Pact. ===1832=== * Santiago del Estero, La Rioja, Tucumán, Salta, San Luis, Catamarca and San Juan join the Federal Pact. * Rosas declines a reelection as governor, the legislature elects [[Juan Ramón Balcarce]]. ===1833=== * Rosas starts the [[Desert Campaign (1833–34)|first conquest of the desert]]. * [[Revolution of the Restorers]] against Balcarce. [[Juan José Viamonte]] replaces him as governor. ===1834=== * Viamonte resigns, and [[Manuel Vicente Maza]] replaces him. ===1835=== * [[Facundo Quiroga]] is murdered in Córdoba. * [[Juan Manuel de Rosas]] is appointed governor, with the [[sum of public power]]. * Rosas established the Customs Law ===1836=== * [[Fructuoso Rivera]] starts a rebellion against Uruguayan president [[Manuel Oribe]]. Birth of the two main Uruguayan parties: Colorados (for Rivera) and Blancos (for Oribe). ===1837=== * Argentina joins the [[War of the Confederation]]. * Execution of the Reinafé brothers, accused of murder of Quiroga. ===1838=== * France imposes the [[French blockade of the Río de la Plata]] to Buenos Aires * Rivera ousted Oribe from power, becoming the new president of Uruguay * Death of [[Estanislao López]], governor of Santa Fe. * Murder of [[Alejandro Heredia]], governor of Tucuman ===1839=== * Rivera declares war to Argentina * [[Berón de Estrada]], governor of Corrientes, declares war to Rosas. He was defeated by Echagüe at Pago Largo. * [[Juan Lavalle]] invades Entre Ríos * Failed conspiracy of Ramón Maza against Rosas. The [[Mazorca]] kills [[Manuel Maza]] during the conflict. * Revolution of the "Libres del Sur" ===1840=== * [[Juan Lavalle]] is defeated by [[Pascual Echagüe]] in [[Entre Ríos Province|Entre Ríos]] at the [[Battle of Don Cristóbal]] (10 April 1840) and the [[Battle of Sauce Grande]] (16 July 1840). * [[José María Paz]] is appointed head of the forces of Corrientes * France lifts the blockade * [[Manuel Oribe]] defeats Lavalle in Córdoba in the [[Battle of Quebracho Herrado]] * [[Domingo Faustino Sarmiento]] moves to Chile. ===1841=== * Oribe defeats Lavalle in the [[battle of Famaillá]]. * Aráoz de Lamadrid is defeated in the [[Battle of Rodeo del Medio]] * Lavalle dies in Jujuy, in a confusing episode * [[Justo José de Urquiza]] is appointed governor of Entre Ríos. ==Bibliography== * {{cite book |title= La época de Rosas |last= Luna |first= Félix |authorlink= Félix Luna |year= 2003 |publisher= La Nación |location= Buenos Aires |isbn= 950-49-1116-1}} {{Argentine Civil War}} {{Argentina topics}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} [[Category:Argentine Civil War]] [[Category:Argentina-related lists]]

'''Tongkah Harbour Public Company Limited''' is a [[mining]] company and property developer in [[Thailand]]. The company was listed on the [[Stock Exchange of Thailand]] (SET:THL) in 1993.<ref name=history>{{cite web|title=History|url=http://www.tongkahharbour.com/tongkah/about_history.html|website=Tongkah Harbour Public Company Limited|accessdate=26 December 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715033837/http://www.tongkahharbour.com/tongkah/about_history.html|archivedate=2014-07-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Investor Relations|url=http://www.tongkahharbour.com/tongkah/investor/en_inves/en_main.html|website=Tongkah Harbour Public Company Limited|accessdate=14 August 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140718040630/http://www.tongkahharbour.com/tongkah/investor/en_inves/en_main.html|archivedate=2014-07-18}}</ref>
The company was founded in 1906 by [[Edward Miles|Edward T. Miles]] as the "Tongkah Harbour Tin Dredging Company N.L." It began offshore tin mining in [[Phuket|Phuket Bay]] in 1907.<ref name=history />
In 1991 the company's subsidiary, [[Tungkum]] Limited (TKL), was founded and granted a concession in the [[Wang Saphung District]] of [[Loei Province]] for the exploration and mining of gold and related minerals.<ref name=history /> [[2014 Loei Gold Mine mob attack|Tungkum]] has been the target of demonstrations by residents living in the vicinity of the gold mine. They accuse the company of environmental destruction.<ref>{{cite web|title=Gold Mine Protesters Hurt by Armed Mob and Shady Deals|url=http://isaanrecord.com/2014/05/20/gold-mine-protesters-hurt-by-armed-mob-and-shady-deals-3/|website=The Isaan Record|accessdate=2 October 2015|date=2014-05-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Mining industry thugs must be stopped|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/print/415247/|accessdate=6 May 2016|work=Bangkok Post|date=2014-06-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Techawongtham|first1=Wasant|title=Time to stop poisoning our precious land, resources|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/opinion/opinion/961017/time-to-stop-poisoning-our-precious-land-resources|accessdate=6 May 2016|work=Bangkok Post|date=2016-05-06}}</ref>
==Tungkum accused of judicial harassment== The Khon Rak Ban Kerd Group (KRBKG) is a community-based group committed to defend the local environment from the negative impacts of the open-pit copper-gold mine operated by the Tungkum Company in [[Loei Province]]. On 30 March 2016, the Loei Provincial Court dismissed a civil defamation lawsuit brought by six KRBKG members who live in communities near the open-pit copper-gold mine, for erecting signs in 2015 at the Na Nong Bong village entrance gate and along the main road in the village, calling for the closure of the controversial mine and rehabilitation of the local environment. Tungkum sought 50 million baht in compensation from the six KRBKG members for alleged damage to the company’s reputation. Tungkum has brought at least 19 criminal and civil lawsuits against 33 members of the KRBKG and other villagers in the past seven years, including the case dismissed yesterday. Using lawsuits, the company has sought a total of 320 million baht from villagers who oppose the mine.<ref>{{cite web|title=Thailand: Judicial harassment against members of the Khon Rak Ban Kerd Group for opposing gold mine|url=http://www.omct.org/human-rights-defenders/urgent-interventions/thailand/2016/03/d23694/|website=World Organisation Against Torture (OMCT)|location=Geneva|date=2016-03-31|accessdate=2018-10-02}}</ref> Following a three-year investigation, the [[NGO]] [[Fortify Rights]] found that the company and the Thai government had "...targeted environmental defenders...journalists, and others with costly lawsuits that infringe on basic rights."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Wannasiri |first1=Sutharee |last2=Smith |first2=Amy |title=Score gold by protecting rights, not mine operations |url=https://www.bangkokpost.com/opinion/opinion/1550378/score-gold-by-protecting-activists-not-mine-operators |accessdate=2 October 2018 |work=Bangkok Post |publisher=Fortify Rights |date=2 October 2018 |format=Opinion}}</ref> Their findings are documented in a 90-page report issued in October 2018.<ref>{{cite book |title='We Fight to Protect our Home'; Reprisals Against Environmental Defenders in Loei Province, Thailand |date=October 2018 |publisher=Fortify Rights |url=https://www.fortifyrights.org/downloads/We_Fight_to_Protect_Our_Home-Fortify_Rights_Report-EN.pdf |accessdate=2 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Thailand: Protect Environmental Defenders, Ensure Remedies |url=https://www.fortifyrights.org/publication-20181002.html |accessdate=2 October 2018 |publisher=Fortify Rights |date=2018-10-02 |format=Press release}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
